results.title: Jeanette Powell
results.creator_credit: ACMI, Lisetta Moscardo and Helen Simondson
results.brief_description: In 1996 Powell became the first female to represent The Nationals in the Victorian Government when she was elected as the Member for the North Eastern Province in the Legislative Council. Powell’s political career began as a Councillor for the Shire of Shepparton. Powell has served as Shepparton Shire President, was appointed a commissioner with the Shire of Campaspe in 1994 and in 2002 Powell was elected as the State Member for Shepparton District. Powell is currently the Shadow Minister for Local Government and the Shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs.
results.description: In 1996 Powell became the first female to represent The Nationals in the Victorian Government when she was elected as the Member for the North Eastern Province in the Legislative Council. results.title: Dr Isabel Joy Bear
results.creator_credit: ACMI, Lisetta Moscardo and Helen Simondson
results.brief_description: Isabel Joy Bear began her extensive career in science in the 1940s and today is an Honorary Fellow with CSIRO Minerals. In the 1960s Bear discovered a number of previously unknown metastable zirconium sulfate hydrates. Joy was appointed a Member of the Order of Australia in 1986 for services to science, particularly in the field of mineral chemistry. She is a fellow of both the Royal Australian Chemical Institute (RACI) and the Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy, and in 1988 became the first woman to receive the Leighton Medal - the RACI’s premier award.
results.description: Isabel Joy Bear began her extensive career in science in the 1940s and today is an Honorary Fellow with CSIRO Minerals. In the 1960s Bear discovered a number of previously unknown metastable zirconium sulfate hydrates. Joy was appointed a Member of the Order of Australia in 1986 for services to science, particularly in the field of mineral chemistry. She is a fellow of both the Royal Australian Chemical Institute (RACI) and the Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy, and in 1988 became the first woman to receive the Leighton Medal - the RACI’s premier award.

results.title: Lecki Ord
results.creator_credit: ACMI, Lisetta Moscardo and Helen Simondson
results.brief_description: Lecki Ord has an extensive career of community involvement and town planning and is a veteran campaigner for sustainable living. She has long been leading the way for women entering fields dominated predominantly by men since starting out as an architect in the 1960s. In 1987 Ord became the first female Lord Mayor of Melbourne and in 1995 became a founding member of the Women’s Planning Network.
results.description: Lecki Ord has an extensive career of community involvement and town planning and is a veteran campaigner for sustainable living. She has long been leading the way for women entering fields dominated predominantly by men since starting out as an architect in the 1960s. In 1987 Ord became the first female Lord Mayor of Melbourne and in 1995 became a founding member of the Women’s Planning Network.
description_for_label: Lecki Ord has an extensive career of community involvement and town planning and is a veteran campaigner for sustainable living. She has long been leading the way for women entering fields dominated predominantly by men since starting out as an architect in the 1960s. In 1987 Ord became the first female Lord Mayor of Melbourne and in 1995 became a founding member of the Women’s Planning Network.

results.title: Gracia Baylor
results.creator_credit: ACMI, Lisetta Moscardo and Helen Simondson
results.brief_description: Gracia Baylor was the first woman President of the Shire of Healesville, now Yarra Ranges Shire Council, and one of the first two women to be elected to the Victorian Legislative Council. Gracia has been an active leader of women’s organisations, including President of the National Council of Women (NCW) of Victoria 1990-93 and President of NCW Australia 1997-2000. In 1999, Gracia was made a Member of the Order of Australia (AM) in recognition of her services to Parliament and women’s affairs. She is a member of two Federal Government Advisory Committees.
results.description: Gracia Baylor was the first woman President of the Shire of Healesville, now Yarra Ranges Shire Council, and one of the first two women to be elected to the Victorian Legislative Council. Gracia has been an active leader of women’s organisations, including President of the National Council of Women (NCW) of Victoria 1990-93 and President of NCW Australia 1997-2000. In 1999, Gracia was made a Member of the Order of Australia (AM) in recognition of her services to Parliament and women’s affairs. She is a member of two Federal Government Advisory Committees.
description_for_label: Gracia Baylor was the first woman President of the Shire of Healesville, now Yarra Ranges Shire Council, and one of the first two women to be elected to the Victorian Legislative Council. Gracia has been an active leader of women’s organisations, including President of the National Council of Women (NCW) of Victoria 1990-93 and President of NCW Australia 1997-2000. In 1999, Gracia was made a Member of the Order of Australia (AM) in recognition of her services to Parliament and women’s affairs. She is a member of two Federal Government Advisory Committees.

results.title: Judy Maddigan
results.creator_credit: ACMI, Lisetta Moscardo and Helen Simondson
results.brief_description: Judy Maddigan was the first woman Deputy Speaker and was the first woman to be appointed the Speaker of The Legislative Assembly in Victoria in 2003. Maddigan has a strong commitment to community and was elected as a Member of Parliament to represent the Electoral District of Essendon in the Legislative Assembly in 1996. During her time as speaker Maddigan implemented many changes in the 150 year old parliament to improve the lives of workers and also public accessibility. She is a librarian at heart and is currently the Member for Essendon.
results.description: Judy Maddigan was the first woman Deputy Speaker and was the first woman to be appointed the Speaker of The Legislative Assembly in Victoria in 2003. Maddigan has a strong commitment to community and was elected as a Member of Parliament to represent the Electoral District of Essendon in the Legislative Assembly in 1996. During her time as speaker Maddigan implemented many changes in the 150 year old parliament to improve the lives of workers and also public accessibility. She is a librarian at heart and is currently the Member for Essendon.

She is a librarian at heart and is currently the Member for Essendon.

results.title: The Road home
results.brief_description: One of the most dramatic stories from a young aspiring filmmaker with autism who lost everything - his home, his camera and film equipment. Starting to rebuild now and a strong family network.

group.title: Living with disaster: stories and experiences from disasters

group_siblings.title: When a fire comes to you

results.title: Into the flames
results.brief_description: A personal account of ‘Black Saturday’ bushfires from a young leader, a volunteer from CFA Region 14. Simon speaks of his experiences fighting the blaze - monitoring where campers are located, through to anger from local residents directed at his crew in the heat and panic of the fires.

results.title: Fire threat
results.brief_description: A young mum recounts her stress at her partner deciding to stay in Warburton while she and her young daughter go to her mum’s house. She speaks about her ‘uni days’ and the change in priorities now that she is a mum.

results.title: In a knot
results.brief_description: ‘Warburton, which is practically my life.’ A sparse story, fairly poetic, about her stress and anxiety and fighting with her family. Amazing photos - from a light plane looking over the ‘Black Saturday’ affected areas.

group_siblings.title: When a fire comes to you

results.title: Black ash
results.brief_description: An account of a typical ‘lazy day’ by the river in Warburton which suddenly turns nasty when Bonnie and her friends realise the gravity of the fire. She recounts her anxiety and wanting to leave Warburton and her frustration at her family’s indecisions. She is stuck in Lysterfield after they evacuate with 17 people.
